meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny! It's time to put on my reviewer hat (which looks suspiciously like a fedora) and dive into the world of Deceive Inc. This sneaky multiplayer game has got everyone talking, from PC Gamer to The Games Machine, but is it worth your attention? Well, let me tell you - I've been playing this spy-em-up for hours, and I'm still trying to figure out how to get the perfect hairdo on my in-game character (spoiler: it involves a lot of gel).

Now, let's get to the review. Deceive Inc. is all about teamwork and strategy, which makes me sound like a total goody two-shoes. You see, instead of just running around with guns blazing (although, let's be real, that can be fun too), you need to work together with your team to complete objectives while avoiding detection by the enemy team.

The game does an excellent job of blending sneaking and shooting in a way that's both creative and engaging. The levels are designed to encourage cleverness and quick thinking, whether it's sneaking past guards or hacking into security systems. And when things go wrong (which they inevitably will), you'll need to think fast to get out of sticky situations.

Now, I know what you're thinking - what about the bugs? Well, let me tell you, they're there, but they're not game-breakers (unless you count my character's hairdo being completely ruined by a glitchy hairstyle update). The devs seem to be on top of things, and they've already released some fixes.

What really impressed me was how the game encourages you to play smartly. You can't just rush in guns blazing like Rambo; you need to think about your objectives and work with your team to achieve them. It's a refreshing change from the usual deathmatch shooters.

Of course, not everyone is singing the same tune. Some critics have mentioned frustrating matches or minor annoyances (I'm looking at you, GameSkinny), but for me, those issues were relatively minor.

Overall, I think Deceive Inc. is a fantastic multiplayer game that's well worth your time. It's got plenty of depth and replay value, and the community seems to be pretty active (although, let's be real, I'm still waiting for someone to play with me).

So, if you're looking for a game that's all about strategy, teamwork, and sneaky spy antics, Deceive Inc. is definitely worth checking out. And hey, who knows - maybe one day I'll even find someone to play with!
